(i) The calculated activation energy of the electrodes according to the Arrhenius equation.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">Additionally, the reaction kinetics of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes were examined by employing CV curves at varying scan rates (as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>b). The relationship between the scan rate (<em>v</em>) and peak current (<em>i</em>) is delineated by Equations <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0010" name="be0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0015" name="be0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>.<span class="display"><span id="e0010" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.196ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 3098.3 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2209,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="e0015" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="20.56ex" height="2.548ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 8852.2 1096.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1446,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2069,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3125,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4571,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5323,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6324,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6920,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8366,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">b</mi><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">b</mi><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where the parameters a and b represent the fitting constants. Here, <em>i</em> denotes the measured peak current (A), and <em>v</em> signifies the scan rate (mV s<sup>−1</sup>). The slope of the log<em>i</em>-log<em>v</em> plots corresponds to the b value, indicative of the electrochemical reaction mechanism. A b value around 0.5 indicates that diffusion-controlled behavior is predominant, whereas a b value close to 1 suggests that capacitive behavior is dominant <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. The b values for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes were computed, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>c. The results reveal that the b value for each peak is approximately 0.9, suggesting that the sodium storage behavior is primarily governed by capacitive behavior. Equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0020" name="be0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(3)</span></span></a> provides further elucidation on the contribution of capacitive behavior <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>.<span class="display"><span id="e0020" class="formula"><span class="label">(3)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="16.226ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 6986 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2654,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3362,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4363,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5338,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>in this context, k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> represents the capacitive behavior, while k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup> denotes diffusion-controlled behavior, with k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> and k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup>​ being distinct fitting parameters.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">The trends in diffusion and capacitance contributions in the CV curves of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode at scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.7&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup> are depicted as a three-dimensional histogram (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d). With an increase in scan rate, there is a gradual rise in capacitive contribution and a corresponding decrease in diffusion contribution. Upon reaching a scan rate of 1&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>, the percentage capacity contribution (highlighted in light blue) for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode is computed to be approximately 92.8&nbsp;% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e), in comparison to 91.7&nbsp;% of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>d). The percentages of capacitive behavior and diffusion-controlled behavior for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes at varying scan rates are consolidated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>e. The findings reveal that as the scan rate escalates from 0.1 to 1&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>, the proportion of capacity contribution for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode amplifies from 81.4&nbsp;% to 92.8&nbsp;%, signifying an enhancement in pseudocapacitive behavior <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">Moreover, the Nyquist plots of the EIS for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes at various temperatures are illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g, h, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S18</span></span></a>. A semicircle, representing the charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) of the electrodes, is discernible in the high-frequency region of the Nyquist plots. The equivalent circuit, derived from fitting the Nyquist plots, is incorporated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S18</span></span></a>a, providing the numerical values of the R<sub>ct</sub>. The findings indicate that the R<sub>ct</sub> values of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode at 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, and 55 ℃ are 7314.0, 3419.0, 1680.0, 898.8, 566.5, 341.3, and 233.8&nbsp;Ω, respectively. Conversely, the R<sub>ct</sub> values of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode at the identical temperatures are markedly lower, with corresponding values of 979.3, 520.9, 311.6, 195.7, 112.6, 77.5, and 56.0&nbsp;Ω. This suggests a superior interfacial charge transfer for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode. To further ascertain the activation energy (Ea) for Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation into MoS<sub>2</sub>, the Butler–Volmer equation and Arrhenius equation are employed collectively to compute the activation energy values during the deintercalation process of Na<sup>+</sup> from the electrode. The associated calculation formulas are detailed in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">supporting information</span></span></a>. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>i, the respective calculations and their fitting results suggest that the activation energy (Ea) for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode is approximately 80.697&nbsp;kJ mol<sup>−1</sup>, which is significantly lower than the 95.986&nbsp;kJ mol<sup>−1</sup> of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode. This implies that the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode facilitates a more rapid transfer of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>.</div></section><section id="s0065"><h3 id="st090" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.4. Electrode morphology characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0160">SEM analysis was utilized to examine the microstructure of MoS<sub>2</sub>-based electrodes prepared with SA, SA-PAH, and SA-PAHB binders, both before and after cycling, to investigate changes in surface morphology. The cycled MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes were disassembled in a glove box and then washed with dimethyl carbonate, with the resulting separator surfaces shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S20</span></span></a>. It can be clearly seen that some of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode has fallen off and adhered to the separator, indicating that its inherent linear structure has weak adhesion. Conversely, no obvious electrode fallout was found adhering to the separator surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes. The SEM images of the original surface morphology of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes are shown in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a, b, c. It can be observed that compared to the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode surface with more cracks and agglomeration and the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode surface with some agglomeration, the MoS<sub>2</sub> and conductive agent (acetylene black) on the surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode are more evenly distributed on the copper foil, with no obvious cracks. After the charge–discharge cycle, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes were disassembled for further observation. The results show that there is some electrode material falling off the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S21</span></span></a>a), which can also be verified from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S20</span></span></a>a, and there are more obvious cracks on the surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S21</span></span></a>b). In contrast, the surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode can still maintain a relatively uniform and crack-free state after cycled (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S21</span></span></a>c). This may be due to the multiple hydrogen bond effects of the SA-PAHB semi-interpenetrating network polymer binder that can tightly adhere MoS<sub>2</sub>, so that the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode will not undergo excessive expansion and contraction during the deintercalation of Na<sup>+</sup>. The SEM cross-sectional images of the electrodes before and after cycling can also prove that the SA-PAHB binder has a certain effect in maintaining the stability of the electrode. For the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode, the electrode thickness increases from the original 8.27 um to 20.00 um after cycling (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>i, l), and the calculated expansion rate is 141.8&nbsp;%, which is much lower than the 265.1&nbsp;% of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g, j) and 172.2&nbsp;% of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>h, k). Therefore, this further confirms that the multiple hydrogen bond effects induced by the SA-PAHB semi-interpenetrating network polymer binder play a crucial role in suppressing the volume change of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-based electrode <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr5.jpg" height="535" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (506KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (506KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. SEM images of pristine (a, b, c) and after cycled (d, e, f). (a, d) The MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode, (b, e) the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode, and (c, f) the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode. Cross-section SEM images of MoS<sub>2</sub> electrode with different binders before and after cycled (g, j) SA, (h, k) SA-PAH, and (i, l) SA-PAHB.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0070"><h3 id="st095" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.5. Practical evaluation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0165">To assess possible real-world applications, a sodium-ion coin full-cell was constructed using MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB as the anode and Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C-PVDF as the cathode. The diagrammatic representation of the coin full-cell is illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a. The CV curve of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell at the second cycle is depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b, where a sharp peak of&nbsp;∼&nbsp;2.64&nbsp;V for the anodic sweep and&nbsp;∼&nbsp;1.31, and&nbsp;∼&nbsp;1.82&nbsp;V for the cathodic sweep can be observed. These observations align with the charge–discharge plateau of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell, which can be substantiated from the charge–discharge curves depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c. Concurrently, the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell achieves a relatively high initial coulombic efficiency of 74.4&nbsp;%, and with the progression of charge–discharge activation, the coulombic efficiency gradually increases from 74.4&nbsp;% (first cycle) to 91.3&nbsp;% (third cycle). The cycle stability of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell was evaluated, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d. A discharge specific capacity of 125.2&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be sustained at 0.5 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 50 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention rate of 54.3&nbsp;% relative to the fifth cycle, and an LED can be lighted up by the coin full-cell in the charged state. Besides, it can be observed that the trends of the charge and discharge specific capacity basically coincide in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d, indicating its relatively high coulombic efficiency. Based on this, the average coulombic efficiency of 96.9&nbsp;% for the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell can be calculated. To understand the cycle stability of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell at different current densities, a rate performance test was conducted, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e. The results show that discharge specific capacities of 149.1, 128.9, 108.7, 90.1, and 70.0&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be achieved, respectively, at current densities of 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1, and 2 A g<sup>−1</sup> for the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell. After returning from 2 to 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>, a discharge specific capacity of 120.0&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be obtained, which essentially restores its original discharge specific capacity, indicating that the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell has good reversibility. Given these results, the SA-PAHB binder demonstrates promising potential for practical application in sodium-ion full-cell.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr6.jpg" height="711" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (488KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (488KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) Diagrammatic representation of sodium-ion coin full-cell. (b) CV curve of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell with a SA-PAHB binder for the anode and a PVDF binder for the cathode during the second cycle. (c) Charging/discharging curves of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell in the first three cycles. (d) Cycling performance (inset) the photo of lighted LED with the coin full-cell and (e) rate capability of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell at various current densities.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="s0075"><h2 id="st100" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170">In conclusion, a new SA-PAHB binder is prepared through free radical copolymerization grafting and multiple hydrogen bonding crosslinking. The binder is applied to the MoS<sub>2</sub> anode of sodium-ion battery half-cells and full-cells. The SA-PAHB, with its semi-interpenetrating network structure, is capable of forming multiple hydrogen bonds, generating hydrogen bond values ranging from –33.89 to −45.49&nbsp;kcal mol<sup>−1</sup> as calculated by DFT, which is beneficial for maintaining the stability of MoS<sub>2</sub>-based electrodes and effectively suppressing the volume changes during the sodiation and desodiation processes. Moreover, the rich polar groups –NH<sub>2</sub> and the variable hydrogen bonding crosslinking points contained in the SA-PAHB binder can effectively promote the rapid diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup> and enhance the kinetic performance of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-based electrodes. Compared to traditional linear structured SA and the grafted SA-based binder (SA-PAH), the electrochemical performance of MoS<sub>2</sub> anode using the SA-PAHB binder, whether in half-cells or full-cells, is significantly improved. In light of the aforementioned, we are confident that the SA-PAHB semi-interpenetrating network polymer is an ideal binder for the MoS<sub>2</sub> anode, for both half-cells and full-cells of SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0080"><h2 id="st105" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175"><strong>Liming Yu:</strong> Writing – original draft, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>An Chen:</strong> Software, Methodology, Data curation. <strong>Ruixian Tang:</strong> Methodology, Data curation. <strong>Fangfang Zhao:</strong> Methodology, Data curation. <strong>Jinjin Li:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition, Formal analysis. <strong>Liangming Wei:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Project administration, Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st110" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section Nayak, L.T. Yang, W. Brehm, P. Adelhelm</div><div id="ref-id-h0015" class="title text-m">From lithium-ion to sodium-ion batteries: advantages, challenges, and surprises</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Angew. Chem., Int. Ed., 57 (2018), pp. 102-120</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary"     function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {

          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));

    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
      <span id="pendo-answer-rating"></span>

          'HTML-CSS': { linebreaks: { automatic: true } },
          SVG: {
            scale: 90,
            linebreaks: { automatic: true }
          }
        });
      </script>
