This study offers insights into the stress behavior of SIBs anodes and sets the stage for developing new binders suitable for anode materials with high specific capacities and significant volume expansion.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr1.jpg" height="480" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (424KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (424KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a) Graphical representation depicting the expansion of MoS<sub>2</sub> anode and illustration of the binder’s working principle. (b) The synthesis process of the semi-interpenetrating polymer network binder (SA-PAHB). (c) Schematic representation of the multiple hydrogen bonding binder (SA-PAHB); the types of hydrogen bonds and their corresponding energies are computed using density functional theory simulations.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">Sodium alginate (SA), Acrylamide (AM), Boric acid and Ammonium persulphate (APS) were obtained from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2-Hydroxyethyl acrylate (HEA) was purchased from Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (NVP/C) was supplied by Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd. PVDF was obtained from Solvay International Trading Co., Ltd. N-Methyl-2-Pyrrolidone (NMP) was purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All reagents were used as received without additional purification.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Synthesis of MoS<sub>2</sub></h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The synthesis of MoS<sub>2</sub> was conducted in accordance with established literature protocols <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Synthesis of the SA-PAH and SA-PAHB binders</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">The SA-PAH solution was prepared by dissolving 0.70&nbsp;g of SA, 2.50&nbsp;g of AM, and 1.02&nbsp;g of HEA in 60&nbsp;g of deionized water. The molar ratio of AM to HEA was maintained at 4:1. The mixture was then stirred mechanically at room temperature (25&nbsp;°C) under an argon atmosphere. Subsequently, the temperature was raised to 60&nbsp;°C, and an aqueous solution of APS, amounting to 0.6&nbsp;% of the total weight of AM and HEA, was incrementally added, followed by continuous stirring for 3&nbsp;h to obtain a 5&nbsp;wt% SA-PAH (4:1) solution, also referred to as SA-PAH without specifying the molar ratio. To determine the optimal addition ratio of AM to HEA, the ratios were adjusted to 2:1 and 1:1, and SA-PAH solutions with these ratios were synthesized using a similar method as described above. All SA-PAH solutions were ultimately diluted to a 2&nbsp;wt% concentration for use as a binder.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">The synthesis of the SA-PAHB solution was conducted upon confirming the optimal ratio of SA-PAH (4:1). To this mixture, 5&nbsp;wt% boric acid and 7.5&nbsp;g of deionized water were added. The solution was then magnetically stirred at room temperature (25&nbsp;°C) for 2&nbsp;h to achieve homogeneity, resulting in a 2&nbsp;wt% SA-PAHB aqueous solution. Additionally, 0.2&nbsp;g of SA was dissolved in 9.8&nbsp;g of deionized water to prepare a 2&nbsp;wt% SA aqueous solution for use as a control group. Photographs of the three different binder solutions are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>.</div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Preparation of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">To examine the effect of different molar ratios of AM to HEA on the electrochemical performance of electrodes, binder solutions with SA-PAH ratios of 4:1, 2:1, and 1:1 were prepared. These binders were mixed uniformly with MoS<sub>2</sub> and acetylene black to create electrode slurries, maintaining a mass ratio of MoS<sub>2</sub>: acetylene black: binder at 7:1:2. The slurries were coated onto copper foil current collectors, dried at room temperature, and then in an oven at 80&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h. The electrodes were cut into 12&nbsp;mm diameter discs and further dried in a vacuum oven at 110&nbsp;°C for 3&nbsp;h. The resulting electrodes were designated as MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (4:1), MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (2:1), and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (1:1). After identifying the optimal AM to HEA ratio, SA and SA-PAHB binders were processed similarly to create electrodes named MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB, respectively.</div></section><section id="s0035"><h3 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. The assembly of sodium-ion half-cells and coin full-cells</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">The pre-prepared electrode discs were assembled into 2016-type coin half-cells within an argon-filled glove box (with less than 0.1&nbsp;ppm H<sub>2</sub>O and O<sub>2</sub>). A metallic sodium counter electrode, a GF/D membrane (Whatman) separator, and an electrolyte comprising 1&nbsp;M NaPF<sub>6</sub> in a 1:1 ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) mixture with 5&nbsp;wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) were used. For the assembly of sodium-ion coin full-cells, the electrode slurry was first prepared by dissolving a mass ratio of 8:1:1 of NVP/C, acetylene black, and PVDF binder in NMP solvent, followed by uniform stirring. The electrode slurry was then coated onto aluminum foil and air-dried at room temperature before being dried in a vacuum oven at 110&nbsp;°C for 8&nbsp;h to obtain the NVP/C-PVDF electrode. The MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode, pre-sodiated for 5 cycles and in a discharged state, served as the anode, while the NVP/C-PVDF acted as the cathode to form the coin full-cells. The mass ratio of cathode to anode was controlled at approximately 4.2:1 <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, and the current density and specific capacity were calculated based on the mass loading of the anode. The separator and electrolyte used for the assembly of the coin full-cells were the same as those used in the previously mentioned sodium-ion half-cells assembly.</div></section><section id="s0040"><h3 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.6. Density functional theoretical calculations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">Hydrogen bond types and bonding energies were calculated using Gaussian 16 software package with Density Functional Theory (DFT) method. Geometry optimizations and frequency calculations were conducted at the B3LYP levels of theory utilizing the 6–311&nbsp;+&nbsp;G(d,p) basis set. Single point energy calculations were also performed using the same functional with 6–311&nbsp;+&nbsp;G(d,p). To improve the accuracy of interaction energy calculations, the counterpoise (CP) correction method was employed to account for the Basis Set Superposition Error (BSSE), ensuring more precise interaction energy values <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>. The bonding energies were obtained using the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="e0005" class="formula"><span>E(interaction)&nbsp;=&nbsp;E(AB)&nbsp;+&nbsp;E(BSSE) – E(A) – E(B)</span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">In this context, E(AB)&nbsp;+&nbsp;E(BSSE) represents the BSSE-correction composite energy.</div></section></section><section id="s0045"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussions</h2><section id="s0050"><h3 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Demonstration of binding mechanism</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">The release of substantial internal stress in the electrodes during the charge–discharge process is particularly significant for anode materials with large volume changes. To reduce the stress generated during sodium deintercalation in MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes in SIBs, a SIPN binder (SA-PAHB) was designed and synthesized. Under the introduction of the boronic acid, a quadruple hydrogen-bonding effect and borate ester bonds are established, firmly encapsulating the MoS<sub>2</sub> anode and effectively mitigating its significant volume changes, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a. To achieve this goal, a polymer, SA-PAH, was synthesized through graft copolymerization under typical free radical polymerization conditions. In addition, boronic acid, rich in polar groups (–OH), was introduced to form a SIPN, with the specific chemical reaction formula displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b. The polar −C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O groups of SA and the –COOH, –OH, –NH<sub>2</sub> multi-sites of the SA-PAHB polymer establish a multi-hydrogen bond structure, generating different types of hydrogen bonds. The main hydrogen bond energy values, calculated through density functional theory simulations (DFT), changed from –33.89 (C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O··H-O-C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>9</sub>O) to −35.06 (C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O··H-O-C), −36.48 (C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O··H-N-C) and −45.49&nbsp;kcal mol<sup>−1</sup> (C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O··H-O-B), as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c.</div></section><section id="s0055"><h3 id="st080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Synthesis and characterization of the SA-PAHB binder and MoS<sub>2</sub> anode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">The successful synthesis of the SA-PAHB binder is characterized by FTIR and XRD, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a, b. The peaks at 3266.6, 1589.4, 1403.6, 1083.8, and 1023.9&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> correspond to the O&nbsp;−&nbsp;H stretching vibration, O&nbsp;=&nbsp;C&nbsp;−&nbsp;O (carboxylate) asymmetric vibrations, O&nbsp;=&nbsp;C&nbsp;−&nbsp;O symmetric vibrations, C-OH, and C&nbsp;−&nbsp;O&nbsp;−&nbsp;C asymmetric vibrations of SA, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>. The FTIR of the SA-PAH polymer synthesis process is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>. Peaks at 3331.4 and 3162.1&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> correspond to N-H stretching in the primary amide, peaks at 1654.2 and 1611.1&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> are attributed to C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O and NH<sub>2</sub> stretching, a peak at 1427.8&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is associated with C-N stretching, and 961.7&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> corresponds to the C&nbsp;=&nbsp;C double bond of AM monomer <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. The peaks at 3429.8, 1725.2, 1178.9, and 984.2&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is assigned to the –OH stretching vibration, the O-C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O stretching vibration, the C-O-C stretching vibration, and the C&nbsp;=&nbsp;C double bond of HEA monomer, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. After graft copolymerization, the C&nbsp;=&nbsp;C double bond peaks of the AM and HEA monomers disappear in SA-PAH, and the C-H stretching vibration peak shifts from 2930.8&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> of SA to 2937.7&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> of SA-PAH, indicating the formation of the SA-based graft copolymer <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. Upon the introduction of boronic acid, the&nbsp;−&nbsp;OH stretching vibration peak of SA-PAHB broadened and shifted to a higher wavenumber of 3200.4&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, compared to the&nbsp;−&nbsp;OH stretching vibration peak of SA-PAH at 3191.7&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>. This change, often referred to as a blue shift, occurs because the boronic acid interacts with the hydroxyl groups, forming new hydrogen bonds or other interactions that increase the bond energy of the&nbsp;−&nbsp;OH groups. Based on the above analysis, this suggests the formation of a physical cross-link structure. Concurrently, the asymmetric and symmetric vibration peaks of O&nbsp;=&nbsp;C&nbsp;−&nbsp;O, originally at 1610.9 and 1413.2&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, moved to lower wavenumbers of 1602.2 and 1409.9&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, confirming the occurrence of chemical bonds or hydrogen bonds between SA-PAH and boronic acid.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr2.jpg" height="378" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (358KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (358KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. (a) FTIR spectra and (b) the XRD patterns of SA, SA-PAH, and SA-PAHB. (c) Rheological property, and (d) frequency-dependent viscoelastic modulus test of SA-PAHB binder solution. (e) N<sub>2</sub> adsorption/desorption isotherms, and (f) SAED patterns of the MoS<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">The XRD patterns of SA, SA-PAH, and SA-PAHB are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b. SA displays two amorphous peaks at 2θ&nbsp;=&nbsp;13.4° and 21.9°. The XRD pattern of AM, presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>, reveals a crystalline structure. After free radical copolymerization grafting, the SA-PAH polymer also shows two distinct amorphous peaks, with shifts to 2θ&nbsp;=&nbsp;13.7° and 22.4°, and a reduction in peak intensity. These shifts and intensity changes indicate the formation of chemical or hydrogen bonds between SA and the AM and HEA, as supported by the molecular weight (<em>Mn</em>) data from GPC in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>. The SA-PAHB polymer, which includes boronic acid, exhibits further weakening and merging of the amorphous peaks, with positions shifting to 2θ&nbsp;=&nbsp;15.3° and 21.5°. This suggests additional chemical or hydrogen bonding between boronic acid and the SA-PAH polymer. Based on the above, we can confirm the successful synthesis of a SIPN of SA-PAHB binder. In addition, NMR spectroscopy tests were also used to confirm the successful synthesis of the SA-PAH and SA-PAHB polymers, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">To understand the physicochemical properties of the SA-PAHB polymer, dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) tests were conducted to characterize the SA-PAHB and SA polymers, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c, d, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>. The variation curves of viscosity with shear rate are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>a. The viscosity of the SA-PAHB polymer decreases with the increase in shear rate, specifically from 2.03 to 0.05&nbsp;Pa·S, indicating that the SA-PAHB polymer is a shear-thinning pseudoplastic non-Newtonian fluid. In contrast, the SA polymer exhibits a similar trend in viscosity with shear rate, but the viscosity value decreases from an initial 0.93 to 0.15&nbsp;Pa·S. Additionally, the frequency-dependent viscoelastic modulus is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>b, clearly confirming that the SA-PAHB polymer exhibits viscous behavior (loss modulus (G″)&nbsp;&gt;&nbsp;storage modulus (G′)) across almost all frequencies, which is also verified by its tan δ value, indicating that the SA-PAHB polymer is controlled by an energy dissipation mechanism during the sample stretching. The SA polymer also exhibits similar viscous behavior, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>b. Based on the above, the SA-PAHB binder indicate its superior mechanical stability characterized by high viscosity and stress relaxation, which are crucial in maintaining the electrode's structural integrity during the sodiation and desodiation processes, as they prevent the detachment of active material from the current collector and accommodate the volume changes of the MoS<sub>2</sub> anode, thereby contributing to the significantly improved cycling stability. Furthermore, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on the SA, SA-PAH, and SA-PAHB polymers to characterize their thermal stability, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>. The results show that SA-PAHB has the highest thermal decomposition temperature, with an initial decomposition temperature of 226.9 ℃, which is higher than 208.7 ℃ for SA and 213.8 ℃ for SA-PAH. This suggests that the multiple hydrogen bond structure brought about by the SA-PAHB semi-interpenetrating network polymer contributes to enhancing the thermal stability of the polymer and also leads to a higher tensile strength of the SA-PAHB polymer (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>), which is beneficial for maintaining the stability of the electrode.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">The preparation and characterization of MoS<sub>2</sub> are referenced from previous literature <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>. Additionally, N<sub>2</sub> adsorption/desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution, as well as selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns characterization were conducted, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e, f, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>. The specific surface area of MoS<sub>2</sub> is 20.459&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e). The (002), (100), (103), and (110) crystal planes are separated in the SAED patterns (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f), indicating the hexagonal phase structure of MoS<sub>2</sub>, which is consistent with previously reported literature <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>. TEM and HRTEM images are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>, confirming that the lattice spacing of MoS<sub>2</sub> is 0.63&nbsp;nm. The large interlayer spacing is beneficial for the intercalation and deintercalation of Na<sup>+</sup>.</div></section><section id="s0060"><h3 id="st085" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with three different binders were employed as working electrodes for sodium-ion half-cells to conduct electrochemical performance tests, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>. To determine the best ratio of AM and HEA grafted onto SA, SA-PAH binders with varying molar ratios were synthesized and evaluated through GPC and electrochemical performance tests, as detailed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>, when the molar ratio of AM to HEA is 4:1, SA-PAH (4:1) has the highest <em>Mn</em> of 620737&nbsp;Da, which is higher than 506351&nbsp;Da for SA-PAH (2:1) and 517108&nbsp;Da for SA-PAH (1:1). Subsequently, MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes prepared with grafted SA-based binders were subjected to cycle stability tests, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>a. The results demonstrate that the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (4:1) electrode exhibits the best electrochemical cycle stability. A discharge specific capacity of 422.6&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can still be maintained at 1 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 200 cycles, with almost no capacity loss relative to the fourth cycle. In contrast, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (2:1) and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (1:1) electrodes can only maintain 324.6 and 269.7&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, with corresponding capacity retention rates of 75.3&nbsp;% and 61.8&nbsp;% relative to the fourth cycle. As for the initial coulombic efficiency, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (4:1) electrode also shows a higher value of 75.7&nbsp;% compared to 71.2&nbsp;% for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (2:1) electrode and 71.8&nbsp;% for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH (1:1) electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>b). Based on the above, it can be confirmed that when the molar ratio of AM to HEA is 4:1, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode exhibits relatively superior performance.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr3.jpg" height="593" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (548KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (548KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Sodium storage performance of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes using SA, SA-PAH, and SA-PAHB binders. (a) Rate capability across different current densities. (b) GCD curves of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with SA-PAHB binder at various current densities. (c) Cycling performance of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with SA, SA-PAH, and SA-PAHB binders at 0.5 A/g<sub>.</sub> (d) Voltage profiles of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with the SA-PAHB binder during the 4th, 50th, 100th, and 200th cycles at a current density of 0.5 A/g. (e) EIS spectra of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with different binders after cycled at 0.5 A/g. (f) Three-dimensional histogram of electrochemical performance of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode with different loads at 0.5 A/g after 200 cycles. (g) Cycling performance of MoS<sub>2</sub>- SA-PAHB electrodes at 10 A/g. (h) Radar maps of contrastive sodium-ion half-cell performances of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with other binders.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">Upon determining the optimal ratio of AM and HEA, the SA-PAH binder was obtained. Subsequently, the SA-PAHB semi-interpenetrating network polymer binder was produced by introducing a 5&nbsp;wt% boronic acid. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a presents the rate performance of MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes, each with an active material loading varying between 0.66 and 0.76&nbsp;mg, tested across a current density range from 0.1 to 10.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The results indicate that, compared to the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrodes, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode exhibits superior rate performance, achieving a discharge specific capacity of 378.5&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 10 A g<sup>−1</sup>, which is higher than the 266.1&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode and 278.1&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode. In comparison to the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode also demonstrates a relatively high discharge specific capacity at different current densities, as validated by the charge–discharge plateaus in the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>. A plausible explanation for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode to maintain a high specific capacity at different current densities could be the introduction of abundant –NH<sub>2</sub> polar groups and the formation of multiple hydrogen bonding crosslinking, which, under their combined effect, favorably facilitate the rapid migration and diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">Cycle stability tests were conducted on MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with three different binders at 0.5 A g<sup>−1</sup>, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c. The active material loading was controlled at approximately 0.7&nbsp;mg, and initially activated for three cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode contributed a discharge specific capacity of 496.1&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in the fourth cycle, and even a discharge specific capacity of 511.2&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> could be maintained at 0.5 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 200 cycles, corresponding to almost no decay rate per cycle. However, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrodes could only sustain discharge specific capacities of 282.9 and 426.1&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, with capacity retention rates of 56.9&nbsp;% and 98.9&nbsp;% relative to the fourth cycle, indicating a decline in capacity. This is further corroborated by the trends observed in the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>. Furthermore, the Coulombic efficiencies (CE) of MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes were evaluated and are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S14</span></span></a>. The initial CE of MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrodes are 73.7&nbsp;% and 70.0&nbsp;%, respectively, slightly lower than that of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode at 78.5&nbsp;%, likely due to the introduction of additional monomers causing increased side reactions. Subsequently, the CE of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode rose to 96.3&nbsp;% in the second cycle, surpassing that of MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes at 95.1&nbsp;% and 95.3&nbsp;%, respectively. Ultimately, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode exhibited a stable average CE of 98.4&nbsp;%, higher than the 98.1&nbsp;% of MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH and 97.7&nbsp;% of MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes, indicating that the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode has a higher efficiency for sodium-ion insertion and extraction throughout the charge–discharge cycles.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">The reaction kinetics of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes are characterized through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e, the EIS of the three electrodes cycled are presented. In the high-frequency region, the semicircle corresponds to the charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>). A smaller R<sub>ct</sub> radius signifies more rapid charge transfer and a lower level of polarization <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. The slope of the curve in the low-frequency region corresponds to the diffusion coefficient of Na<sup>+</sup>, with a larger slope indicating a relatively high diffusion coefficient <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. Compared to the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrodes, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode exhibits a smaller R<sub>ct</sub> value in the high-frequency region and a larger slope in the low-frequency region, indicating a faster process of Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation and deintercalation. Furthermore, to meet the practical needs of industrial production, higher loading of MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes were obtained by applying a thicker coating of electrode slurry to achieve active material loadings of 1.0 and 1.2&nbsp;mg. The MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB (1.0&nbsp;mg) and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB (1.2&nbsp;mg) electrodes can achieve discharge specific capacities of 336.1 and 357.7&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.5 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 200 cycles, respectively, with corresponding capacity retention rates of approximately 72.7&nbsp;% and 78.4&nbsp;%, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S15</span></span></a>. Compared to the discharge specific capacity of 511.2&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and almost no capacity loss of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB (0.7&nbsp;mg) electrode, this suggests that the SA-PAHB binder can be used to prepare higher loading electrodes, which have promising prospects in practical production and life.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">To further highlight the advantages of the SA-PAHB binder, electrochemical cycling performance tests were conducted on three different electrodes at a higher current density of 1 A g<sup>−1</sup>, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S16</span></span></a>. The MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes could maintain discharge specific capacities of 218.7, 364.8, and 427.8&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 220 cycles, respectively, with corresponding capacity retention rates of 47.2&nbsp;%, 86.4&nbsp;%, and 93.2&nbsp;% relative to the fourth cycle. This suggests that the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode is capable of stable cycling performance at both low and high current densities. In addition, cycle stability tests for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode at an ultra-high current density of 10 A g<sup>−1</sup> were conducted, with 0.1 and 1 A g<sup>−1</sup> used for activation for five cycles each, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g. The results show that a discharge specific capacity of 267.4&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be achieved for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode after 305 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention rate of 81.7&nbsp;% relative to the eleventh cycle. As per the preceding discussion, we can confirm that the SA-PAHB binder has a fairly good effect in maintaining the electrochemical stability of the MoS<sub>2</sub> anode of the SIBs, which may be due to the multiple hydrogen bond effects induced by its semi-interpenetrating network polymer structure. Furthermore, the electrochemical performance of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode and its comparison with other relevant literature from five dimensions are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>h.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0140">The electrochemical kinetic performance of MoS<sub>2</sub> anodes with SA-PAHB and SA binders was assessed by analyzing cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (0.01–3.00&nbsp;V versus Na/Na<sup>+</sup>, at a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>), as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>a. In the initial cycle of CV curves for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode, only cathodic peaks at approximately 0.01&nbsp;V and 0.79&nbsp;V were discernible, which are ascribed to Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation, SEI layer formation, and the conversion of Na<sub>x</sub>MoS<sub>2</sub> to Na<sub>2</sub>S/Mo <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. The CV curves demonstrated stability in the following two cycles, suggesting a highly reversible and stable sodiation/desodiation process. During the inaugural scan, two anodic peaks were identified at approximately 0.44&nbsp;V and 1.55&nbsp;V, which were less pronounced than the 0.94&nbsp;V and 1.61&nbsp;V (indicated by an arrow) of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>a), signifying improved Na<sup>+</sup> extraction dynamics <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr4.jpg" height="594" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (602KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (602KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) CV curves for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode during the first three cycles at a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV/s, and (b) at varying scan rates. (c) Linear fits of anodic and cathodic peak currents as a function of scan rates for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode. (d) Three-dimensional histogram of diffusion and capacitive contribution at scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.4 and 0.7&nbsp;mV/s. (e) CV profile of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode showing capacitive contribution at a scan rate of 1.0&nbsp;mV/s, and (f) diffusion and capacitive contribution at various scan rates for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode. (g) The EIS of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode at different temperature (inset) equivalent circuit model, and (h) enlargement of (g) with the range of 0&nbsp;−&nbsp;1300. (i) The calculated activation energy of the electrodes according to the Arrhenius equation.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">Additionally, the reaction kinetics of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes were examined by employing CV curves at varying scan rates (as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>b). The relationship between the scan rate (<em>v</em>) and peak current (<em>i</em>) is delineated by Equations <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0010" name="be0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0015" name="be0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>.<span class="display"><span id="e0010" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.196ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 3098.3 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2209,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="e0015" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="20.56ex" height="2.548ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 8852.2 1096.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1446,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2069,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3125,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4571,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5323,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6324,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6920,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6C"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F" x="278" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-67" x="779" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8366,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">b</mi><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">b</mi><mi is="true">log</mi><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where the parameters a and b represent the fitting constants. Here, <em>i</em> denotes the measured peak current (A), and <em>v</em> signifies the scan rate (mV s<sup>−1</sup>). The slope of the log<em>i</em>-log<em>v</em> plots corresponds to the b value, indicative of the electrochemical reaction mechanism. A b value around 0.5 indicates that diffusion-controlled behavior is predominant, whereas a b value close to 1 suggests that capacitive behavior is dominant <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. The b values for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes were computed, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>c. The results reveal that the b value for each peak is approximately 0.9, suggesting that the sodium storage behavior is primarily governed by capacitive behavior. Equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0020" name="be0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(3)</span></span></a> provides further elucidation on the contribution of capacitive behavior <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>.<span class="display"><span id="e0020" class="formula"><span class="label">(3)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="16.226ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 6986 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2654,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3362,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4363,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5338,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>in this context, k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> represents the capacitive behavior, while k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup> denotes diffusion-controlled behavior, with k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> and k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup>​ being distinct fitting parameters.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">The trends in diffusion and capacitance contributions in the CV curves of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode at scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.7&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup> are depicted as a three-dimensional histogram (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d). With an increase in scan rate, there is a gradual rise in capacitive contribution and a corresponding decrease in diffusion contribution. Upon reaching a scan rate of 1&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>, the percentage capacity contribution (highlighted in light blue) for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode is computed to be approximately 92.8&nbsp;% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e), in comparison to 91.7&nbsp;% of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>d). The percentages of capacitive behavior and diffusion-controlled behavior for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes at varying scan rates are consolidated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S17</span></span></a>e. The findings reveal that as the scan rate escalates from 0.1 to 1&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>, the proportion of capacity contribution for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode amplifies from 81.4&nbsp;% to 92.8&nbsp;%, signifying an enhancement in pseudocapacitive behavior <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">Moreover, the Nyquist plots of the EIS for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrodes at various temperatures are illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g, h, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S18</span></span></a>. A semicircle, representing the charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) of the electrodes, is discernible in the high-frequency region of the Nyquist plots. The equivalent circuit, derived from fitting the Nyquist plots, is incorporated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S18</span></span></a>a, providing the numerical values of the R<sub>ct</sub>. The findings indicate that the R<sub>ct</sub> values of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode at 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, and 55 ℃ are 7314.0, 3419.0, 1680.0, 898.8, 566.5, 341.3, and 233.8&nbsp;Ω, respectively. Conversely, the R<sub>ct</sub> values of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode at the identical temperatures are markedly lower, with corresponding values of 979.3, 520.9, 311.6, 195.7, 112.6, 77.5, and 56.0&nbsp;Ω. This suggests a superior interfacial charge transfer for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode. To further ascertain the activation energy (Ea) for Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation into MoS<sub>2</sub>, the Butler–Volmer equation and Arrhenius equation are employed collectively to compute the activation energy values during the deintercalation process of Na<sup>+</sup> from the electrode. The associated calculation formulas are detailed in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">supporting information</span></span></a>. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>i, the respective calculations and their fitting results suggest that the activation energy (Ea) for the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode is approximately 80.697&nbsp;kJ mol<sup>−1</sup>, which is significantly lower than the 95.986&nbsp;kJ mol<sup>−1</sup> of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode. This implies that the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode facilitates a more rapid transfer of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>.</div></section><section id="s0065"><h3 id="st090" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.4. Electrode morphology characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0160">SEM analysis was utilized to examine the microstructure of MoS<sub>2</sub>-based electrodes prepared with SA, SA-PAH, and SA-PAHB binders, both before and after cycling, to investigate changes in surface morphology. The cycled MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes were disassembled in a glove box and then washed with dimethyl carbonate, with the resulting separator surfaces shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S20</span></span></a>. It can be clearly seen that some of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode has fallen off and adhered to the separator, indicating that its inherent linear structure has weak adhesion. Conversely, no obvious electrode fallout was found adhering to the separator surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes. The SEM images of the original surface morphology of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes are shown in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a, b, c. It can be observed that compared to the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode surface with more cracks and agglomeration and the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode surface with some agglomeration, the MoS<sub>2</sub> and conductive agent (acetylene black) on the surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode are more evenly distributed on the copper foil, with no obvious cracks. After the charge–discharge cycle, the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA, MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH, and MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrodes were disassembled for further observation. The results show that there is some electrode material falling off the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S21</span></span></a>a), which can also be verified from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S20</span></span></a>a, and there are more obvious cracks on the surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S21</span></span></a>b). In contrast, the surface of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode can still maintain a relatively uniform and crack-free state after cycled (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0090" name="bs0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S21</span></span></a>c). This may be due to the multiple hydrogen bond effects of the SA-PAHB semi-interpenetrating network polymer binder that can tightly adhere MoS<sub>2</sub>, so that the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode will not undergo excessive expansion and contraction during the deintercalation of Na<sup>+</sup>. The SEM cross-sectional images of the electrodes before and after cycling can also prove that the SA-PAHB binder has a certain effect in maintaining the stability of the electrode. For the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode, the electrode thickness increases from the original 8.27 um to 20.00 um after cycling (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>i, l), and the calculated expansion rate is 141.8&nbsp;%, which is much lower than the 265.1&nbsp;% of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g, j) and 172.2&nbsp;% of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>h, k). Therefore, this further confirms that the multiple hydrogen bond effects induced by the SA-PAHB semi-interpenetrating network polymer binder play a crucial role in suppressing the volume change of the MoS<sub>2</sub>-based electrode <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr5.jpg" height="535" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (506KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (506KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S138589472409497X-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. SEM images of pristine (a, b, c) and after cycled (d, e, f). (a, d) The MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA electrode, (b, e) the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAH electrode, and (c, f) the MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB electrode. Cross-section SEM images of MoS<sub>2</sub> electrode with different binders before and after cycled (g, j) SA, (h, k) SA-PAH, and (i, l) SA-PAHB.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0070"><h3 id="st095" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.5. Practical evaluation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0165">To assess possible real-world applications, a sodium-ion coin full-cell was constructed using MoS<sub>2</sub>-SA-PAHB as the anode and Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C-PVDF as the cathode. The diagrammatic representation of the coin full-cell is illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a. The CV curve of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell at the second cycle is depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b, where a sharp peak of&nbsp;∼&nbsp;2.64&nbsp;V for the anodic sweep and&nbsp;∼&nbsp;1.31, and&nbsp;∼&nbsp;1.82&nbsp;V for the cathodic sweep can be observed. These observations align with the charge–discharge plateau of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell, which can be substantiated from the charge–discharge curves depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c. Concurrently, the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell achieves a relatively high initial coulombic efficiency of 74.4&nbsp;%, and with the progression of charge–discharge activation, the coulombic efficiency gradually increases from 74.4&nbsp;% (first cycle) to 91.3&nbsp;% (third cycle). The cycle stability of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell was evaluated, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d. A discharge specific capacity of 125.2&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be sustained at 0.5 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 50 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention rate of 54.3&nbsp;% relative to the fifth cycle, and an LED can be lighted up by the coin full-cell in the charged state. Besides, it can be observed that the trends of the charge and discharge specific capacity basically coincide in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d, indicating its relatively high coulombic efficiency. Based on this, the average coulombic efficiency of 96.9&nbsp;% for the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell can be calculated. To understand the cycle stability of the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell at different current densities, a rate performance test was conducted, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e. The results show that discharge specific capacities of 149.1, 128.9, 108.7, 90.1, and 70.0&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be achieved, respectively, at current densities of 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1, and 2 A g<sup>−1</sup> for the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell. After returning from 2 to 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>, a discharge specific capacity of 120.0&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> can be obtained, which essentially restores its original discharge specific capacity, indicating that the MoS<sub>2</sub>//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C coin full-cell has good reversibility.
